title: How to Get Coffee Out of a White Shirt: Stain Removal & Prevention

steps.title: Presoak most fabrics with dish soap and vinegar.
steps.content: Presoak most fabrics with dish soap and vinegar. If it’s still fresh, Gholian says to “gently rub coffee stain with a clean, dry cloth.” [1] X Expert Source Jon Gholian Cleaning Specialist Expert Interview. 19 April 2021 Then, presoak the stain with a mixture of 1 quart (946 ml) warm water, 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 ml) of dish soap, and 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of white vinegar. Let it soak for 15 minutes, then rinse with clean, warm water. If the stain remains, blot it with a sponge and rubbing alcohol before washing as usual. Only put the shirt in the dryer if you’re 100% sure the stain is gone, as the heat may set it further. [2] X Research source This method works for shirts made of synthetic fabrics (like nylon, polyester, and spandex), as well as cotton. If your shirt is made of a specialty fabric, like silk, fur, or leather, it’s best to have it professionally cleaned, as these materials can easily be damaged. Sometimes, a mixture of just water and vinegar will be enough to remove the stain. Alternatively, pretreat the stain with liquid laundry detergent and let it sit for about 5 minutes before running the white shirt through the wash. Stocker says you can “absolutely” use both vinegar and detergent when washing your clothes, “But you cannot mix them together. If you are using detergent, only use the vinegar in the rinse cycle after the detergent is out. You’ll get oily clothes otherwise.” [3] X Expert Source Susan Stocker House Cleaning Professional Expert Interview. 8 November 2019.

steps.title: Presoak old stains with an enzymatic cleaner for 30 minutes.
steps.content: Presoak old stains with an enzymatic cleaner for 30 minutes. Older coffee stains are more stubborn, but they can still be removed! Mix 1 quart (946 ml) of warm water with 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of an enzymatic presoak or stain remover in a large bucket or basin. Immerse your white shirt for 30 minutes, then check to see if the stain is gone. If it is, wash the shirt as you normally would, then let it air dry. [4] X Research source Enzymatic presoaks are commercial stain removers that use enzymes in their formulas to help break down organic stains. Stain removers work particularly well with cotton fabrics. If the stain is still there, try soaking it for another half an hour or give one of the other cleaning techniques a try. If the stain is small, a stain pen may be enough to remove it.

steps.title: Pour hot water over cotton if pretreating doesn’t work.
steps.content: Pour hot water over cotton if pretreating doesn’t work. If you already tried pretreating a stained cotton shirt and the stain remains, stretch the stained area of fabric over a bowl and secure it with a rubber band. Heat some water in a kettle until it reaches 200 degrees F (93 degrees C), then pour it directly over the stain. Be careful not to burn yourself, and make sure the material is 100% cotton, as the hot water may damage some dyes and finishes. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Remove set-in stains with bleach.
steps.content: Remove set-in stains with bleach. Diluted bleach is safe to use on natural fabrics, like cotton and linen. Mix 1/4 cup (60 ml) of chlorine bleach and 1 gallon (3.8 L) of water in a large bucket or basin. [6] X Trustworthy Source State of Michigan Official website for the State of Michigan Go to source Submerge the shirt in the solution and soak it for 5 minutes. Then, rinse the shirt with cold water,run it through a normal wash cycle, and let it air dry. Alternatively, launder the shirt with bleach. Add a cap full of bleach to the washing machine drum as it fills up with cold water, then add the shirt and run the cycle. Avoid using bleach to treat coffee stains on spandex, wool, silk, mohair, or leather clothing. It’s best to take those fabrics to a dry cleaner. Warning: Do not mix bleach with other cleaning solutions, as this could create toxic fumes. Work in a well-ventilated area and wear gloves to avoid touching it. [7] X Trustworthy Source State of Michigan Official website for the State of Michigan Go to source

steps.title: Spot treat minor stains with club soda.
steps.content: Spot treat minor stains with club soda. If you’re in a pinch, club soda is a quick and easy way to treat minor stains. Remove the stained garment (if possible) and pour the club soda directly onto the coffee stain. Then, gently blot the area with a paper towel until the stain lifts. If possible, hang the shirt up to air dry, then toss it in the wash as soon as you can. [8] X Research source Repeat this process as many times as you'd like. Club soda probably isn’t realistic if you’re dealing with a large coffee stain. This method also works to remove coffee stains from tablecloths and carpets .

steps.title: Apply baking soda to keep the stain from spreading.
steps.content: Apply baking soda to keep the stain from spreading. First, blot the coffee stain with a cold, damp paper towel. Then, sprinkle some baking soda over it and let it sit for a while to soak up the coffee. Then, blot the area again with a clean, dry paper towel. Alternatively, mix some baking soda with a few drops of water and apply the paste directly to the stain. Let it sit for a few minutes, then rinse with clean water. [9] X Research source Salt also works to prevent fresh stains from spreading. Generously sprinkle it all over the stain and let it sit for a few minutes before wiping it away with a paper towel. Stocker adds that baking soda “brightens clothes and removes odors. In the house cleaning business, we use it for our cleaning cloths, as well, to remove any odors. And if you mix baking soda and vinegar together, it actually kills 99% of bacteria!” [10] X Expert Source Susan Stocker House Cleaning Professional Expert Interview. 8 November 2019.

steps.title: Soak up fresh coffee stains with baby powder.
steps.content: Soak up fresh coffee stains with baby powder. Baby powder is a great way to soak up oils, including those in coffee. If the stain is still fresh, pour some baby powder directly onto the affected area and let it soak in for a few minutes. Then, gently brush it off with a clean, dry cloth. The baby powder may not remove the stain completely, but it should make it easier to clean. [11] X Research source If you’re on the go, blotting the fresh stain with a baby wipe can also help remove it or prevent it from spreading.

steps.title: Don’t put the shirt in the dryer unless the stain is completely gone.
steps.content: Don’t put the shirt in the dryer unless the stain is completely gone. The heat from your dryer will permanently set a lingering stain, so inspect the garment carefully to make sure there are no traces of the stain. If the shirt looks totally clean, go ahead and toss the garment in your dryer and dry it as you normally would. If you’re not sure or want to play it safe, air dry the shirt instead. [12] X Research source If the stain persists, try running it through another wash cycle using enzymatic laundry detergent.

steps.title: Choose a cup with a lid.
steps.content: Choose a cup with a lid. Accidents can happen no matter what, but putting a lid on your coffee is a great way to keep from spilling it. This is especially true if you’re walking, in your car, or around important technology. It may be better to save your favorite mug for a day you’re relaxing at home.

steps.title: Clean up spills as soon as possible.
steps.content: Clean up spills as soon as possible. The quicker you act, the less likely the coffee will set in. If possible, take your white shirt off immediately and flush it with cold, running water, especially if the stain is large. If you can’t, hold a dry paper towel under the stain and dab the area with a wet cloth or sponge. Then, machine wash the garment as soon as possible. [13] X Research source Always use cold water for this! Hot water will permanently set the stain into the fabric.

steps.title: Coffee stains because it contains oils and tannins.
steps.content: Coffee stains because it contains oils and tannins. Tannins are plant compounds that create the brown residue of a coffee stain. [14] X Research source Coffee also contains oils that can coat fabric and make them resistant to water, which in turn makes the stain harder to remove. Many people also add ingredients like sugar, cream, and syrup to their coffee, which contain even more oils.

steps.title: Are coffee stains permanent?
steps.content: Are coffee stains permanent? Set-in coffee stains may be a bit difficult to remove, but coffee stains aren’t usually permanent, as they’re water-based stains. The key is to act quickly and get the brown tannins to dissolve in water. Pretreating the stain with dish soap and vinegar or laundry detergent will usually do the trick. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Will a coffee stain go away on its own?
steps.content: Will a coffee stain go away on its own? No, coffee stains must be treated for them to go away. The longer a coffee stain is left to sit, the harder it will be to remove. [16] X Research source Soak up as much excess as possible and flush the stain with cold water as soon as possible. Then, use one of the above methods to remove the stain completely.

steps.title: How long does it take for coffee to leave a stain on clothes?
steps.content: How long does it take for coffee to leave a stain on clothes? Coffee can stain practically as soon as the spill happens. This is why it’s important to treat the stain as soon as possible so it doesn’t set in. [17] X Research source Do not put the stained garment in the dryer until you’re certain the stain is gone, or the heat could make it even harder to remove.
